data.text:
A Cure for Spring Fever by Barbara Robinson (Part of the Jelly Beans & Spring Things Series) | Excerpt ~ $20 Gift Card Available | #ParanormalRomance #novella #BookTour @GoddessFish @BarbaraRobinsonWrites @WildRosePress

A book blog tour from Goddess Fish Promotions.

Thank you to the author, publisher, and Marianne & Judy at Goddess Fish for providing me with the information for this tour.

Book Details

Quick Snippet:

When Gamekeeper Stan Ross’s magic begins to fail, he embarks on a journey to the Sacred Isle in search of answers. His quest takes an unexpected turn when he encounters a captivating kitchen witch, Lynnette Peters, who is healing from her own wounds.

A Cure for Spring Fever by Barbara Robinson

Series: Part of Jelly Beans and Spring Things

Published by The Wild Rose Press on April 22, 2024

Genres: Fiction, Paranormal, Romance

Format: eBook

Pages: 73

For centuries, Gamekeepers have used their magical abilities to create a buffer between the creatures who dwell in the enchanted forest and the sleepy coastal town that sits in its shadow. When Gamekeeper Stan Ross’s magic begins to fail, he must find out what went wrong, then fix it before the two worlds collide. His hit or miss magic has already led to a few close calls so he journeys to the Sacred Isle searching for answers and advice.

Finding a cure proves elusive—until Stan encounters a kitchen witch who captivates him body and soul. Lynnette Peters is healing from her own wounds, however, and it isn’t clear whether she’s ready to open herself to the possibility—or the peril—of love.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Excerpt from A Cure for Spring Fever

The sun’s rays already had strength, even through the partial shade of the forest. It was only nine o’clock, but Stan could tell it was going to be one of those late spring days that felt more like early summer. The forest was alive with activity, and crowds were beginning to enter through the open gate. No cars were permitted, but the gamekeepers had a shuttle service to take people from one area to another if they preferred not to use the network of trails. He and Owen were scheduled to deliver their first performance in just a few minutes, and he noticed parents beginning to mill about the interpretive station with their little ones.

The kids seemed to enjoy the 3-D models of mystical creatures, and some were listening to videoclips, but Old Gus was the main attraction of the pregame show. At ten years old, the Basset Hound had proven himself to be an expert tracker, helping to round up stray creatures when they escaped the confines of their forest home.

He sported his trademark Ranger’s hat and green vest this morning, and a little crowd of children had already gathered around him, trying to get him to bay at them. The old boy was a real ham, and he didn’t mind singing if it earned him more treats. Stan and Owen would be giving a talk on the enchanted forest as

a living habitat, but Gus was the star of the show.

The presentation was off to a good start, with the kids paying as much attention as could be expected when you brought them together outdoors. Some were pulling up small pieces of grass to throw at their neighbours, others were engrossed in looking for insects and spiders, and a few were even paying attention to what he was saying.

“Can anyone tell me how old the trees in enchanted forest are? Anyone?” he asked, scanning the crowd.

Then he caught sight of her, and for a moment he couldn’t remember what he’d been talking about.

Excerpt provided by the author/publisher for use in this post.

About Barbara Robinson

Barbara Robinson is an author of contemporary and historical romance set against a backdrop of magical realism. She is a deep thinker and tea drinker who finds inspiration in myths and folktales, poems and ballads, and academic writing on a variety of subjects. Diagnosed with autism and giftedness as an adult, she enjoys exploring themes of neurodiversity and opposing character perspectives in her writing.

She is an avid gardener and lover of nature who works out plot lines and character sketches while nurturing her garden, walking in the woods, or sitting by the shoreline watching waves. She is known for world building that features rich and immersive detail, supported by meticulous research and careful observation.

Barbara lives in Nova Scotia, Canada, in the shadow of ancient mountains that lie along the Bay of Fundy coast. These rugged vistas shape her story settings, while providing the perfect backdrop for life with her husband, her hounds and her dragon (Pogona Vitticeps). She has a Bachelor of Arts from the University of King’s College and a Master of Arts at Dalhousie University, and she recently completed a Graduate Certificate in Creative Writing from the Humber School for Writers (Humber College, Toronto).
